metadata.case_name: L. Hazarimal Kuthiala v. Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala & Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The appellant firm, L. Hazarimal Kuthiala of Kapurthala, carried on business as forest lessees and timber merchants at Dhilwan in the former Kapurthala State.
In Kapurthala State, an income-tax law was in force, and prior to integration on April 10, 1947, the income of the firm for the account year 1945-46 (Samvat 2002) was duly assessed, and tax was paid.

Kapurthala integrated into PEPSU, and the Rajpramukh issued two Ordinances in Samvat 2005, by which all laws in force in Kapurthala including the income-tax law ceased to be operative from August 20, 1948; Patiala Income-tax Act, 2001, came into force.

Indian Finance Act, 1950 (26 of 1950), applied the Indian Income-tax Act to Part B States; Section 13 repealed income-tax laws in Part B States except for levy, assessment and collection of income-tax and super-tax for defined periods.

On November 4, 1953, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab I, Himachal Pradesh, Bilaspur and Simla, purporting to act under section 5(5) and 7A of the Indian Income-tax Act, ordered that assessment of the appellant firm be done by Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala, instead of Income-tax Officer, B-Ward, Patiala (competent under section 64).

On March 12, 1955, Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala, issued notice under section 34 of Patiala Income-tax Act of Samvat 2001 calling for return of income and world income, believing income under-assessed.

Appellant firm moved High Court of Punjab under Article 226 for writs of prohibition, certiorari, quo warranto etc. against ITO Ambala and CIT; High Court dismissed petition but granted certificate under Arts. 132 and 133; appeal filed.

Numerous objections raised on competency of proceedings; some no longer pressed: Art.14, reassessment under Patiala not Kapurthala law, Sec.13 of Finance Act 1950 not including reassessment (abandoned per Shenoy and Guruswamy).
Respondents stated reassessment, if any, under Kapurthala law as in assessment year Samvat 2002.

legal_issues.text: Whether Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala had jurisdiction to issue notice under section 34, and whether Commissioner of Income-tax's transfer order dated November 4, 1953 was ultra vires and incompetent, only ITO B-Ward Patiala competent under section 64.

petitioner_arguments.text: CIT referred to Indian Income-tax Act not Patiala Act; if Patiala Act in force for reassessment, action under Patiala Act required.
Under Patiala Act s5(5), CIT required to consult Minister-in-charge (CBR post Finance Act); no consultation, and CIT purported under Indian Act where no such need.
Transfer only under s5(7A) for individual cases; no pending case, no explanation like in Indian Act post-Bidi Supply; s5(5) for distribution not individual transfers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Patiala Income-tax Act s5(5), s5(7A); Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Plural words in s5(5) ('persons or classes') indicate groups, not individual; s5(5) makes s7A otiose if overlapping.

respondent_arguments.text: Reassessment under Kapurthala law as existed in Samvat 2002.
Exercise of power referable to valid jurisdiction (Patiala Act), not nugatory one.
Consultation with CBR directory, not mandatory; failure does not invalidate.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava; K.S. Srinivasan v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: s5(5) covers non-pending cases as distribution/allocation of work; Commissioner mentioned in both s5(5) and s7A; no pending case so s5(5) applies; plural includes singular.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Patiala Income-tax Act s5(5), s5(7A); Bidi Supply (not under s5(5))

court_reasoning.text: Power exercise referable to jurisdiction conferring validity (Patiala Act), per settled principle.
court_reasoning.key_observation: CIT's reference to Indian Act loses point; valid under Patiala.

court_reasoning.text: Patiala s5(5) required consultation with Minister (CBR); but provision directory per Manbodhan Lal, Srinivasan, Montreal Railway (PC), Biswanath Khemka; neglect does not invalidate acts in public duty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure to consult CBR does not render order ineffective; administrative control only.

court_reasoning.text: s5(7A) for pending cases only (per Bidi Supply reasoning, no explanation in Patiala); non-pending cases under s5(5) as distribution of work.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No pending case; s5(5) allows directing ITOs for persons/areas, plural includes singular.

court_reasoning.text: No otiose provisions; s7A special for pending, s5(5) general; duplication common (e.g. CPC s24, Letters Patent); where no pending case, s5(5) available.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order valid as arrangement for disposal by particular ITO under s5(5).

holdings.text: Commissioner's transfer order valid under s5(5) of Patiala Income-tax Act as directory consultation and power for non-pending cases; ITO Ambala has jurisdiction.

Income-tax Officer, Bangalore v. K.N. Guruswamy
Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: s.5(7A) Indian IT Act for pending cases only; led to explanation

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
K.S. Srinivasan v. Union of India
Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions for public duty directory if neglect causes inconvenience without promoting object

precedents_cited.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Affidavit on reason for s5(7A); but affidavit not aid to construe

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition; certificate for appeal; equality abandoned

statutes_cited.name: Patiala Income-tax Act, Samvat 2001
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice for reassessment; transfer powers; consultation required in s5(5)

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: CIT purported under these; comparable provisions; s64 local jurisdiction

statutes_cited.name: Indian Finance Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied Indian IT Act to Part B States; repealed local laws except for assessment/reassessment

outcome.summary: The appeal against dismissal of writ petition challenging jurisdiction of ITO Ambala and validity of CIT's transfer order is dismissed; transfer held valid under Patiala IT Act s5(5).

key_quotes.text: "The exercise of a power will be referable to jurisdiction which confers validity upon it and not to a jurisdiction under which it will be nugatory."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle upholding CIT's order under Patiala Act

key_quotes.text: "The provision about consultation must be treated as directory, on the principles accepted by this Court in State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Failure to consult CBR does not invalidate

key_quotes.text: "When the provisions of a statute relate to the performance of a public duty and the case is such that to hold null and void acts done in neglect of this duty would work serious general inconvenience... it has been the practice to hold such provisions to be directory only."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Montreal Railway explaining directory nature

key_quotes.text: "The plural including the singular, the order of the Commissioner was valid, because he arranged and distributed work."
key_quotes.speaker: court
